item.description: The Bunbury Magistrates Court hears how Stanley J Clemons shot his neighbour's dog and discarded its body, which still has not been found.

item.description: Despite the comfortable series win over South Africa, Australia is mindful it will need to step up a gear in the Constellation Cup against New Zealand.

item.title: Red Bull admits fault over 'clearly incorrect' suggestion Kimi Antonelli allowed Lando Norris to overtake him
item.description: Red Bull retracts suggestions made by its engineer that Mercedes driver Kimi Antonelli deliberately let Lando Norris overtake him at the Qatar Grand Prix.

item.title: Papua New Guinea calls for 'buffer zone' with Indonesia amid concerns over West Papua conflict
item.description: Australia, Papua New Guinea and Indonesia have started holding annual defence ministers meetings to build trust and boost military cooperation, while PNG proposes building a 10km-wide demilitarised "buffer zone" along its border with Indonesia.

item.title: Teen becomes first nationally accredited netball umpire in a wheelchair
item.description: Brodie Taylor has changed the game of netball by overturning disability preconceptions to become the first person in a wheelchair to attain national netball umpiring accreditation.

item.description: Oscar Piastri dodges the question of whether he might help Lando Norris lift the world F1 title in Abu Dhabi, saying McLaren has not discussed the issue.

item.description: After finishing last in his first race, Oscar Piastri has risen from humble beginnings to the brink of Australian sporting history as he chases his first F1 world title.

item.description: Max Verstappen reacts as Helmut Marko's retirement leaves Red Bull without its two main guiding personalities since its entry into F1.

item.title: Bathurst childcare worker sentenced after dragging and throwing child

item.description: Police have arrested a 37-year-old man for the alleged murder of a woman who was found unresponsive in Adelaide's parklands in January.

item.description: A group dedicated to Australian grain farming created more than a decade ago has just cracked 100,000 followers with about 20,000 people following from overseas.

item.title: Record year for Australian beef exports despite Donald Trump's tariffs
item.description: When Donald Trump enforced a 10 per cent tariff on Australian beef, there were some concerns it would impact trade. But the opposite happened.

item.title: Mother wallaby death sparks animal cruelty investigation in far north Queensland
item.description: Wildlife carers have lodged formal complaints with police and environment officials after stumbling across a scene involving a dead mother wallaby tied to a signpost.

item.title: Country league president reported to AFL integrity unit over alleged 'gender weirdness' comments
item.description: A country football league president has been reported to the AFL Integrity Unit over alleged comments about a club's "grooming and gender weirdness" after it was involved in blocking the club from entering a neighbouring competition.

item.title: What it's like working at Casey Station in Antarctica
item.description: From 6,000 applications each year, only about 300 make the cut to travel down to Antarctica and experience a workplace like no other.

item.title: Japan begins test mining seabed for rare earth minerals to reduce reliance on China
item.description: Tokyo hopes the plan to mine as much as 16 million tonnes of rare earths will help reduce its reliance on China, but will it work?

item.title: Woman dies after tree falls on her car south of Wollongong as winds and rain lash NSW coast
item.description: Emergency services were called to the Illawarra Highway near Clover Hill Road just before 4pm after a tree branch fell onto a passing vehicle on a busy road.

item.title: How charging board or rent to adult children can help them and you
item.description: Experts on the benefit of charging board and expenses if you’re sharing a home with young adults, and how to calculate it.

item.title: How lifting gave me back the power to feel good at sport
item.description: As a child, Julie "wasn't one of the sporty kids". A safe gym environment and then a supportive powerlifting community helped her realise that wasn't actually true.

item.title: Brooklyn Beckham has cut ties with his famous parents. What can we learn from it?
item.description: Celebrity family rifts are not new. Experts weigh in on how they can spark negative feelings about our own family dynamics.

item.title: Kittens left for third time in Greenacres Library's after-hours book return chute
item.description: The RSPCA is investigating after CCTV footage appears to show a man leaving four young cats at a library in the city's north-east.

item.title: China's air force has technology that rivals the US's and it could be pivotal in any conflict over Taiwan
item.description: Certain capabilities of China's air force now seriously challenge those of the US and other Western countries, with experts saying that it could tip the balance of any war over Taiwan in Beijing's favour.

item.title: Gold surges, ASX falls as 'sell America' trade hits Wall St — as it happened
item.description: The Australian share market has fallen for a third straight day as Wall Street tumbled to a one-month low on worsening relations between the US and Europe.

item.title: Mackay council gives evicted rough sleepers 24 hours to move on from riverfront
item.description: Mackay Regional Council tells rough sleepers evicted from riverfront camps to pack up and move within 24 hours.

item.title: Climate change increased the chance of intense Australian heatwave fivefold, study finds
item.description: A study by World Weather Attribution has analysed temperatures during the intense early January heatwave. It found that what was once a rare event is now happening far more often.

item.title: triple j's Hottest 100 of 2025 — when it happens, how to listen and more
item.description: Australia's favourite music poll is back for another year — here's when it happens and how to listen.

item.title: Canberra woman to face court after allegedly assaulting airline crew member on flight to Perth
item.description: Police say the 52-year-old woman "forcibly grabbed the arm and head" of a crew member, causing them minor injuries, as the plane was preparing to take off from Canberra on December 13.

item.title: Decision to suspend Tasmanian councillor Louise Elliot for 'child-like' comments upheld in court
item.description: A Tasmanian councillor says she is being "censored and unfairly punished" after being sanctioned for social media posts she made regarding a fellow councillor.

item.title: Adelaide swelters through night as 'extreme' fire danger forecast across South Australia
item.description: Authorities are urging South Australians to be vigilant and "make good choices" as "extreme" fire danger is forecast for the southern half of the state.

item.title: Woman discovers Holocaust descendants through DNA testing
item.description: Adriana Turk grew up believing there were no survivors on her Jewish father's side after World War II, but a DNA test showed that was not the case.

item.title: Should you leave the air con on for your pets?
item.description: Do you wonder what your pet gets up to at home when you're not there? With temperatures on the rise, we asked three experts about keeping them cool in the heat.

item.title: Glenorchy City Council knocks back a proposal from Hobart to merge
item.description: Tasmania is a small place with many councils, 29 in fact. A proposal to merge Hobart with neighbouring Glenorchy has been knocked back with the latter saying it would be too costly and there's no community support for it.

item.title: Three brothers among 35 killed as freezing conditions grip US
item.description: Much of the US was not forecast to get above freezing all day on Tuesday, local time, with temperatures plunging again overnight.

item.title: Tongans frustrated with Trump's 'collective punishment' of foreign nationals
item.description: The United States bars Tongans from short-term visits or travel for tourism and business purposes, saying too many are overstaying their visas.

item.title: Music rights body says Australian artists are struggling to find streaming audiences at home
item.description: While this year's triple j Hottest 100 featured a significant number of Australian songs, local artists have suffered a shocking decline in online streaming figures over the past five years.

item.title: David Speirs sees 'pathway' to standing for election amid eligibility questions
item.description: Former South Australian Liberal leader David Speirs says there is a way he could stand for the upcoming state election — but is yet to declare whether he will — despite the electoral commission declaring he is ineligible.

item.title: Former employee accused of defrauding three NSW local councils by more than $1 million
item.description: Martin Thomas Dimec is facing more than 40 charges of fraud after police allege he stole the money from Murrumbidgee, Shoalhaven and Goulburn councils across 12 years of employment.

item.title: Shoppers remember 'old days' at grocery store that has operated since late 19th century
item.description: A New South Wales grocery store has been operating since before there was refrigeration, electricity and even Vegemite.

item.title: Genetically modified purple tomatoes bound for fruit shops after regulator approval
item.description: The purple tomato was altered to make it taste better and boost nutrition.

item.title: Rare earths mine at centre of Trump-Albanese deal yet to materialise after years in the making
item.description: It is the Central Australian mine promised to help upset China's dominance of the rare earths market worldwide, and bring hundreds of jobs to Australia. But where is it?

item.title: Fugees, Weezer, Spiderbait's classic albums turn 30 in 2026
item.description: From Weezer's raw emotion to the Spice Girls's pop revolution, revisit 10 iconic albums that made 1996 a landmark year in music. Thirty years on, they still define the era.

item.title: Hastie rules out challenge to Sussan Ley for Liberal Party leadership
item.description: The West Australian backbencher had made no secret of his desire to lead the Liberal Party but says he will not run against Sussan Ley next week, a move which could pave the way for Angus Taylor.

item.title: Mimili artists talk of Country, community, survival in remote APY Lands
item.description: The artists of Mimili, in the APY Lands of South Australia, are using new methods to share crucial knowledge of Country and culture, including repurposed car parts.

item.title: Millions of dollars projected for flood-affected north-west Queensland graziers to rebuild
item.description: Graziers are looking at a tough few years and millions of dollars to restock cattle herds as the recovery begins in outback Queensland after widespread flooding hit the north-west.

item.title: Kakadu National Park's Jabiru Airport slated for demolition from October
item.description: Kakadu's main airport, which services a wide and remote corner of the Northern Territory, has been slated for demolition as the deadline for the nearby uranium mine's rehabilitation looms.

item.title: Kambalda's future unclear on 60th anniversary of nickel discovery
item.description: This week marks 60 years since one of Australia's biggest mineral discoveries put Kambalda on the map. But now all the WA town's nickel mines have closed and the prospect of a future restart is unclear.

item.title: Bruny Island to get childcare solution but too late for the Archers
item.description: After fighting for years for a childcare solution for her community, Teisha Archer says the news it will be happening is "wonderful" — but will come too late to help her and others in her situation.

item.title: First Nations people say 'silence' on alleged Perth bomb attack weighs heavily
item.description: Underwhelming public responses in the wake of the alleged attack on an Invasion Day rally in Perth leave First Nations people across Australia feeling their "pain matters less".

item.title: Trump administration eyes US Pacific territories as it moves towards deep-sea mining
item.description: A Trump administration push to begin deep-sea mining is gathering momentum — and stirring alarm in United States Pacific territories.

item.title: Inside the brand strategy behind the Beckham family drama — and who controls the narrative now
item.description: In a modern crisis, experts say control doesn't always come from speaking louder — but from knowing when, where and how briefly to speak at all.

item.title: Carlos Alcaraz has his never-before moment by beating Novak Djokovic in his own house
item.description: Carlos Alcaraz has defeated Novak Djokovic in a pulsating Australian Open final, becoming the youngest man with a career Grand Slam in the process.

item.title: Bad Bunny makes Grammys history with Album of the Year win — as it happened
item.description: Debí Tirar Más Fotos is the first Spanish-language record to win Album of the Year at the Grammy awards.

item.description: The best and most memorable red carpet looks at the 68th Annual Grammy Awards.

item.title: From Sabalenka to Djokovic and 'animals in the zoo', here are the best quotes from the Australian Open 2026
item.description: From tennis stars pushing for more privacy, to Djokovic saying he feels like an old man and a Kyrgios F-bomb, there have been some funny and weird quotes at this year's Australian Open.

item.title: Found a PCOS 'cure' on social media? It might not be for you
item.description: Advice on how to "manage", "treat" and "heal" PCOS is easy to come by online, but experts say a more personalised approach is usually what's needed.

item.title: Aussie dollar climbs as RBA raises rates and leaves door open to more hikes — as it happened
item.description: The Reserve Bank has hiked the cash rate 0.25 percentage points to 3.85 per cent, in its first rate rise in more than two years. The Aussie dollar rose back above 70 US cents after the decision.

item.title: Behind the music of hit Australian indie game Hollow Knight: Silksong
item.description: The video game soundtrack will be performed live for the first time by Orchestra Victoria at ACMI in February.

item.title: Belinda Bencic and Elina Svitolina make history as two mothers sit in WTA top 10 for the first time
item.description: For the first time in women's tennis, two mothers are ranked inside the world's top 10 simultaneously.

item.title: Sam Kerr is back for the Asian Cup, half a lifetime after winning it as a teenager
item.description: Matildas captain Sam Kerr was just 16 when she helped the team win the Women's Asian Cup — their first, and to date only major trophy. Now she's leading the side at home, ready for another shot at glory.

item.title: Boost for development of low-emissions alternatives to glass wine bottles
item.description: The federal government provides $2 million towards developing low-emissions alternatives to glass wine bottles using materials like seaweed and plant sugar.

item.title: Rockhampton residents supporting the homeless as council considers rough sleepers' hub
item.description: Cheryl Dolan felt a sense of desperation as she walked through the parks of her central Queensland city. Now, she is taking action and calling for change.

item.title: Up to 100,000 dead fish found on bank of Lake Menindee
item.description: Residents of a far west New South Wales community found tens of thousands of dead fish on the banks of Lake Menindee.

item.title: Art exhibitions to see this summer, from Ron Mueck to Hobart Current and Olafur Eliasson
item.description: From Aussie expat Ron Mueck's hyper-realistic sculptures and Icelandic Danish artist Olafur Eliasson's thought-provoking installations to the best contemporary artists in Tasmania, here are three exhibitions to see.

item.title: Banned tennis player Thomas Fancutt makes comeback after IV vitamin breach
item.description: Thomas Fancutt has made his return to professional tennis after receiving a 10-month ban for a vitamin and magnesium infusion.

item.title: Bill Gates denies allegations in new Epstein files release
item.description: Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates denies ever visiting Jeffrey Epstein's private island after new claims surfaced following the release of files from a US government investigation into the late sex offender.

item.title: Report points to exploitation, Medicare and visa concerns in Pacific islander jobs scheme
item.description: Changing jobs is a basic right for most people, but it is not so simple for Pacific Australia Labour Mobility workers.

item.title: In Zak Hilditch's horror movie We Bury the Dead, the zombie apocalypse devastates Tasmania
item.description: These Final Hours writer and director Zak Hilditch drew on personal tragedy to produce We Bury the Dead, his biggest cinematic epic yet.

item.title: New resource connects people with organisations on front lines of bushfire relief effort
item.description: A new online resource aims to make it easier for people to contribute to bushfire relief efforts across Victoria.

item.title: NSW government contacts Newcastle Writers Festival about author Randa Abdel-Fattah's inclusion
item.description: The NSW government makes contact with the board of next month's Newcastle Writers Festival about the inclusion of Palestinian-Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah, the ABC understands.

item.title: Diamonds defeat Jamaica in first netball Test match in Adelaide
item.description: The Diamonds made a flying start with the initial six goals in a comprehensive 72-41 victory at the Adelaide Entertainment Centre.

item.title: Zombie movie We Bury The Dead set in Tasmania, but filmed in WA due to cost
item.description: Despite being set in Tasmania and featuring Hobart being blown to pieces in an explosion, a new zombie horror movie starring Star Wars heroine Daisy Ridley had to be filmed in WA because of "logistical" challenges.

item.title: Racehorse owner charged after gelding found dead on Maryborough property
item.description: A six-year-old gelding had career winnings of $90,000 before it was found dead on a central Victorian property.

item.title: US hopes to challenge China's critical minerals dominance with new trading bloc
item.description: The US is urging dozens of countries to follow Australia's lead and sign on to a plan to stop relying on China for the critical minerals used in modern technology.

item.title: What Israel's President Isaac Herzog has said about Gaza, and why he won't be arrested in Australia
item.description: When Israel's president lands in Australia this weekend, he can expect an official red carpet treatment. But he will be all too aware of the controversy his visit is generating.

item.title: Karnivool's new album In Verses was worth the 13-year wait, bagpipes and all
item.description: They're one of Australia's most revered heavy acts. And arguably the most patient. Karnivool unpack the 13-year journey to their new album, In Verses.

item.title: Georgia Voll helps Royal Challengers Bengaluru win Indian Women's Premier League
item.description: Royal Challengers Bengaluru pulled off the biggest successful chase in the Women's Premier League to win their second title in the Indian franchise-based T20 league.

item.title: French authorities sink tonnes of cocaine bound for Australia, then release suspects
item.description: French authorities intercept a ship carrying five tonnes of cocaine bound for Australia, before releasing the vessel and its crew.

item.title: Premier Chris Minns says Newcastle Writers Festival 'crazy' to invite author Randa Abdel-Fattah
item.description: The festival's director said Dr Abdel-Fattah was invited in August last year and denied the state government pressured her to remove the writer.

item.title: Josh Hazlewood out of T20 World Cup with injury in another blow to Australia's hopes
item.description: Josh Hazlewood is ruled out of Australia's T20 World Cup campaign as he continues to recover from the injuries which kept him from playing in the summer's Ashes series.

item.title: Perth council in 'respectful' disagreement over spending choices on meals and rent
item.description: A newly elected councillor in the Shire of Serpentine-Jarrahdale, in Perth's outer-eastern fringe, accuses the shire of making poor spending choices with ratepayers' money.

item.title: Vaibhav Sooryavanshi, India's 14-year-old batting prodigy, breaks records in Under-19 World Cup final
item.description: The 14-year-old prodigy Vaibhav Sooryavanshi breaks Alyssa Healy's record with the highest score ever in a World Cup final to power India to the global under-19 crown.

item.title: What you need to know about skiing in Japan and how to keep yourself safe on the slopes
item.description: Australians flock to Japan each year to take advantage of its unique and plentiful snow, but it's not just the travel costs that are mounting.

item.title: Karratha residents warned to prepare for 200km/h winds as Tropical Cyclone Mitchell intensifies
item.description: While avoiding a direct hit, Karratha is still expected to feel the force of the category three cyclone as it tracks along the Pilbara coast tonight.

item.title: Xavier Rudd on visiting Echuca, playing solo, and the spiritual being that follows him
item.description: Xavier Rudd performs solo these days, but he carries a spirit with him wherever he goes.

item.title: Big swings in Australia's electricity market have a frustrating effect on our power bills
item.description: The benefits of extremely low energy prices during the day are "washed away" by extremely high ones after dark. But there is light at the end of the tunnel.

item.title: Australia's men and women unbeaten in Perth Sevens to set up semifinal opportunities
item.description: Australia makes a hot start to the Rugby Sevens in Perth, with both the men's and women's teams going unbeaten in securing semifinal berths.

item.title: As the West wakes up to the reality of the Epstein class, China plans a global reserve currency
item.description: As the West reacts to the revelations in the latest batch of Epstein files, China has plans for the renminbi to become a global reserve currency.

item.title: Tasmania looks at allowing public hospital midwives to help with homebirths
item.description: The Tasmanian government is developing a public homebirth model that would allow midwives working in the public system to support women to labour from their homes.

item.title: Before opening Meg's Bookshop in 1991, the Arnolds were told kids 'didn't read' in Port Pirie
item.description: In one of Australia's most disadvantaged regions, more known for its lead than its literature, a couple wanted to open a book store but were told children didn't read books there. They did it anyway, and it went on to become a "world class" institution.

item.title: 3 Doors Down frontman Brad Arnold dies after stage four cancer battle
item.description: Brad Arnold, a founder and the lead singer of American rock band 3 Doors Down, dies nine months after revealing he had kidney cancer.

item.title: WA photographers reminisce about bygone Goldfields era as gold's price surges
item.description: In 1989, two photographers travelled from Fremantle to Western Australia's Goldfields to capture the end of a gold mining era.

item.title: One Nation capitalises on anti-immigration sentiment in a housing crisis
item.description: Pauline Hanson might not have any substantive policies, but her rhetoric about reducing migration is clearly finding an audience.

item.title: Young people could get massive pay boost in 'totemic' wage case
item.description: Hardworking young people are sweating on a key wage case that could boost their pay, while businesses warn it could cause a collapse in employment.

item.title: Japan PM Sanae Takaichi leads coalition to landslide election victory
item.description: Sanae Takaichi's Liberal Democratic Party and its coalition partner are expected to hold upwards of two-thirds of the seats in Japan's lower house.

item.title: Thailand PM Anutin Charnvirakul confident of forming government after election
item.description: South-East Asia's second-largest economy went to the polls on Sunday in a tight race between conservatives aligned with the military and the monarchy, and progressive elements represented by the reform-driven People's Party.

item.title: Why Payne Haas's move from Brisbane to South Sydney changes the game for two NRL giants
item.description: Payne Haas's decision to leave Brisbane for South Sydney in 2027 didn't just shock the rugby league world, it transformed the futures of two of rugby league's most powerful clubs in an instant.

item.title: Raw sewage overflows leave Lowood families sick, anxious and financially trapped
item.description: Residents in a small-town west of Brisbane say more than a decade of raw sewage overflows during heavy rain has left them dealing with serious health issues and ongoing anxiety.

item.title: Explain the Internet: Why Wuthering Heights is one of the year's most controversial adaptations
item.description: Days away from the release of Emerald Fennell's highly anticipated adaptation of Emily Brontë's classic novel, critics and fans alike are still fighting about text fidelity in the comments.

item.title: Deua River Valley and Cobargo still rebuilding six years after Black Summer bushfires
item.description: Residents who lived through the 2019-20 bushfires on the NSW South Coast say this summer's fires triggered traumatic memories, and highlighted the recovery and resilience projects that remain unfinished.

item.title: Liberals despair at prospect of 'non-existence' and weigh leadership change after catastrophic Newspoll
item.description: Sussan Ley could face a challenge to her leadership from Angus Taylor this week after a disastrous opinion poll showed the Coalition parties falling further behind One Nation.

item.title: 'Punitive' bail law amendments have increased and First Nations people are affected
item.description: A study has found increasing "punitive" bail law amendments are negatively affecting First Nations people.

item.title: Thousands rally around Australia as protests against Herzog's visit turn violent— as it happened
item.description: Thousands of people have gathered across Australia to protest the visit of Israeli President Isaac Herzog.

item.title: Backyard pods won't fix the housing crisis but they signal a shift
item.description: Australia's biggest hardware retailer has started selling tiny homes. Are backyard pods the answer to a national housing crisis?

item.title: Iran sentences Nobel Peace Prize winner Narges Mohammadi to six more years in prison
item.description: Women's rights activist Narges Mohammadi is sentenced to a further six years in jail.

item.title: Hong Kong media mogul Jimmy Lai sentenced to 20 years in landmark case
item.description: Jimmy Lai, one of Hong Kong's most outspoken critics of China, has learned his fate after being sentenced this morning.

item.title: Rain brings relief and road closures after record heatwave in South Australia
item.description: High rainfall in north-eastern South Australia brings some relief for pastoralists after record-breaking heat, with a reprieve expected for metropolitan Adelaide this week.

item.title: Bad Bunny's Super Bowl half-time show features surprise guests Lady Gaga and Ricky Martin
item.description: Global superstar Bad Bunny performs at the Super Bowl LX, sharing the stage with surprise guests Lady Gaga and Ricky Martin, while a couple weds on stage.

item.title: Daly River expected to surpass major flood level before reaching peak
item.description: Flooding at the Daly River community is expected to surpass the major flood level late Monday, with a peak of 14.1 metres expected by Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: Police and protesters clash in Sydney rally against Israeli President Isaac Herzog's visit to Australia
item.description: Thousands of people attend protests across the country against Israeli President Isaac Herzog's visit to Australia in the wake of the Bondi terror attack, with demonstrators in Sydney sprayed with pepper spray and led away in handcuffs.

item.title: Sanae Takaichi's stomping victory will have profound consequences for Australia and the Asia-Pacific
item.description: A stomping victory by the ruling coalition government of Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi has opened the way for a major geo-strategic realignment in the Asia-Pacific region, with big implications for Australia.

item.title: Monday Finance with Alan Kohler
item.description: News from the world of finance and business. Top stories in text, video and audio. Business video news bulletin. Features and analysis.

item.title: ASIO was told about Bondi shooter's terrorist links years before attack, former spy claims
item.description: The former undercover agent spied on the Akrams when he infiltrated a Sydney IS terror cell for Australia's intelligence agency.

item.title: Tasmanian cartoonist Jon Kudelka and the art of cutting through political spin
item.description: Hailed as an artist who "knew the power of comedy in holding truth to power", Jon Kudelka once described himself as "like a monkey with an automatic rifle".

item.title: Brisbane Broncos captain Adam Reynolds holds hope of Payne Haas contract backflip
item.description: Brisbane prop Payne Haas is set to arrive in England for the World Club Challenge where his teammates will try to convince him not to honour his deal with South Sydney.

item.title: More people say they'll vote One Nation. What are they voting for?
item.description: One Nation questions if man-made climate change is real, wants to wind back access to abortion care and plans to pay the HECS debts of doctors working in the regions.

item.title: Roblox on notice after 'disturbing' reports of child grooming
item.description: The government puts popular social gaming site Roblox on notice following media reports of children being approached and groomed by predators on the platform.

item.title: Painkillers and HRT therapies among drugs not being subsidised under PBS
item.description: Painkillers, HRT therapies and incontinence medicines are among the drugs that will not benefit from the new maximum $25 script price.

item.title: St Kilda star Max King injured again, Port ruckman Ivan Soldo out for season
item.description: Max King has suffered another injury, further frustrating the St Kilda key forward's bid for an AFL return.

item.title: How AI is disrupting the tech boom on global markets
item.description: Amongst tech investors the penny has finally dropped about just what the future may hold, and many are backing off or at least rethinking their strategy.

item.title: Pakistan reverses cricket T20 World Cup boycott and will face India in Sri Lanka
item.description: Pakistan has ‍agreed to play India ​in the ⁠T20 World Cup match scheduled to take ‌place in Colombo this ‍Sunday, February 15.

item.title: Angus Taylor faces pressure to challenge for Liberal leadership
item.description: Liberal leadership aspirant Angus Taylor is facing pressure from conservative supporters to challenge Sussan Ley this week and end the damaging speculation paralysing the party.

item.title: A nod to her Olympic legacy as former premier Annastacia Palaszczuk's portrait unveiled in parliament
item.description: Former Queensland premier Annastacia Palaszczuk's parliamentary portrait contains a small nod to her Olympic legacy.

item.title: Swifts Creek faces tough task of reinventing itself amid job losses
item.description: Job losses mean Swifts Creek in Victoria's High Country is facing an identity crisis, but it is not the only small town undergoing a transformation.

item.title: Catherine O'Hara's cause of death revealed as pulmonary embolism
item.description: Award-winning actress Catherine O'Hara died from a pulmonary embolism, according to her death certificate.

item.title: Commonwealth asks to meet Roblox following reports of child grooming. Here's what we know
item.description: Roblox has been called to an urgent meeting with the federal government in the wake of reports that children are being groomed by predators and exposed to sexually explicit material on the popular online gaming platform.

item.title: Grace Tame criticised for leading intifada chants at Sydney protest
item.description: Grace Tame accuses Australia of being "a so-called democracy" that punishes peaceful protesters, before chanting "from Gadigal to Gaza, globalise the intifada!"

item.title: Deadline looms for Warren Tredrea to pay Nine's legal costs after failed appeal against unfair dismissal case
item.description: Former footballer Warren Tredrea has an imminent deadline to pay $149,000 to his former employer, Channel Nine, following a failed appeal against an unfair dismissal case.

item.title: Man charged after police allegedly find more than 125,000 files of child abuse material
item.description: A man appears in court after police officers seize a mobile and laptop with allegedly more than 125,000 files of child abuse material.

item.title: Tuesday finance with Alan Kohler
item.description: News from the world of finance and business. Top stories in text, video and audio. Business video news bulletin. Features and analysis.

item.title: Liberals plot resignations to pave way for leadership challenge
item.description: Liberals are bracing for a wave of frontbench resignations as soon as Wednesday to pave the way for Angus Taylor to mount a leadership challenge against Sussan Ley.

item.title: Three key moments in police clashes with Sydney protesters
item.description: Competing narratives have emerged from NSW Police and protesters who were at Monday night's demonstration near Sydney's Town Hall. ABC NEWS Verify has gathered footage and spoken to witnesses in an early attempt to examine what happened in detail.

item.title: Bulk-billing rates rebound on back of government's multi-billion-dollar policy
item.description: Bulk-billing rates have rebounded in the first clear measure of the impact of the government's multi-billion-dollar pledge.

item.title: Rental affordability hits record low as rents rise 2.5 times faster than wages, analysis shows
item.description: Tenants now pay an average of 33.4 per cent of their pre-tax income on rent, which is the highest level on record, according to a property research firm.

item.title: The desperate toll of Australia's 2026 Winter Olympic Games injury chaos
item.description: Games-ending injuries to Cam Bolton and Misaki Vaughan have emphasised the dangers of winter sport as the Australian team copes with issues early in the Milano Cortina Games.

item.title: Protesters were punched, pushed, and arrested but were NSW Police actions excessive?
item.description: What is reasonable? It's a question being asked by some after footage of clashes in Sydney's CBD, during a rally against Israeli President Isaac Herzog's visit.

item.title: Iran's rulers face 'defections and disobedience', but will it be enough to topple the regime?
item.description: As talks between Washington and Tehran over a nuclear deal continue, fractures within the regime are starting to emerge.

item.title: How 'capacity constraints' are linked to inflation and your hip pocket
item.description: It may sound boring, but "capacity constraints" are to blame for your higher mortgage repayments.

item.title: Angus Taylor resigns from Liberal frontbench ahead of expected leadership spill — as it happened
item.description: Angus Taylor has resigned from the shadow frontbench ahead of an expected Liberal leadership spill.

item.title: Hand-built high country bridges lost to fires, taking decades of history with them
item.description: Volunteers are weighing the future of the High Country Rail Trail after the loss of 12 historic trestle bridges — and decades of work — to bushfires.

item.title: Commonwealth Bank shares rise after CBA reports increased profits as it lifts home lending volumes
item.description: CBA's net profit for the first half of the financial year rose 5 per cent to $5.367 billion, beating analyst expectations, on the back of increased lending and deposit volumes.

item.title: Milano Cortina 2026 is the most gender-equal Winter Olympics ever, aside from Nordic Combined
item.description: Nordic Combined is the only sport at any Olympic Games — summer and winter — that does not have an event for women. It's an omission that is putting the entire future of the sport at risk.

item.title: Flood ruins costly repairs to Savannahlander railway bridge before it is used
item.description: Flooding knocks a heritage-listed bush rail bridge out of alignment only weeks after long-awaited repairs, jeopardising the future of the Savannahlander route.

item.description: Follow the latest headlines from ABC News, Australia's most trusted media source, with live events, audio and on-demand video from the national broadcaster.

item.title: Doongmabulla Springs decision leaves Qld government to weigh appeal or face trial
item.description: Wangan and Jagalingou peoples await the state government's next move after a win in their fight to have alleged damage to a sacred site near a mine in Central Queensland investigated.

item.title: Indonesia readies up to 8,000 troops for Board of Peace efforts in Gaza
item.description: The move makes Indonesia the first country to clearly commit troops to a multinational peacekeeping effort in the war-torn enclave.

item.title: Telstra to axe up to 650 roles in mass redundancy round, some jobs to be outsourced to India
item.description: Telstra notifies staff of plans to outsource hundreds of jobs to an India-based technology company.

item.title: Israeli President Isaac Herzog welcomes 'new beginning' in meeting with Anthony Albanese
item.description: Israeli President Isaac Herzog meets with the prime minister at Parliament House in Canberra, saying his visit to Australia has been "very emotional".

item.title: Austin Appelbee's Triple Zero call to save family swept out to sea at Geographe Bay released
item.description: Police release the recording of the Triple Zero call made by 13-year-old Austin Appelbee after his marathon 4 kilometre swim through rough seas to save his family.

item.title: Australia cruises to victory over Ireland in T20 World Cup opener
item.description: Australia beats Ireland by 67 runs to win its first game at the T20 World Cup, after captain Mitch Marsh was a late out due to testicular bleeding.

item.title: Channel Nine says Warren Tredrea has now paid costs over long-running legal battle
item.description: Channel Nine has confirmed it has received legal costs from former AFL player and sports presenter Warren Tredrea, who was ordered to pay $149,000 to his ex-employer.

item.title: Albanese 'determined to succeed' as Closing the Gap deadline looms
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is bullish on closing the gap between Indigenous and non-Indigenous people ahead of handing down his annual report card on the progress made.

item.title: Xi Jinping says China's army has undergone 'revolutionary tempering' in corruption crackdown
item.description: Xi Jinping's comments were the first public admission of issues in China's armed forces since an investigation was launched into senior members of the body that overseas the country's military.

item.title: Angus Taylor is moving to challenge Sussan Ley — but not on his terms
item.description: Angus Taylor was holidaying in Europe when his colleagues began manoeuvring to topple Sussan Ley. A leadership spill this week wasn't what he or Sussan Ley wanted.

item.title: Transparency concerns as Bougainville mine that sparked civil war on path to reopen
item.description: The Autonomous Bougainville Government signs a secretive deal to reopen a huge gold and copper mine that sparked a catastrophic civil war three decades ago.

item.title: Australia's toxic legacy at Wilkes Station in Antarctica
item.description: The ABC has been given rare access to an abandoned Australian base in Antarctica that continues to pose a threat to the environment.

item.title: Old Bureau of Meteorology website still getting thousands of clicks
item.description: The new BOM website is still drawing criticism, with 400,000 users turning to the old site, despite $1.15 million in recent updates.

item.title: The weekend Adelaide becomes a Saudi Arabian sports utopia
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s LIV Golf project is facing plenty of problems across the world, but you would not read about it when the circus flies into Adelaide.

item.title: Australia Diamonds defeat Jamaica 80-33 in third netball Test to claim 3-0 series win
item.description: Coach Stacey Marinkovich believes a refreshed Diamonds squad has found its "identity" ahead of attempting to become the first Australian netball team to defend Commonwealth Games gold.

item.title: A look at the ballistic missile program Iran refuses to negotiate on
item.description: Iran has spent decades building the largest and most diverse ballistic missile stockpile in the Middle East and is refusing US demands to put limits on the weapons program.

item.title: Animal abuse charge takes one year as RSPCA prosecutions in Queensland drastically decline
item.description: A man has been charged with animal cruelty a year after neighbours first made a complaint to the RSPCA.

item.title: Lando Norris quickest on day one of F1 preseason test, Oscar Piastri drives well and Max Verstappen impresses
item.description: McLaren's Formula 1 world champion Lando Norris was fastest on the first day of preseason testing in Bahrain, but Max Verstappen and Red Bull caught the attention with pace and plenty of laps.

item.title: Baker Boy talks new album Djandjay, Riverboats festival and family legacy
item.description: The Yolŋu artist known as the Fresh Prince of Arnhem Land is the king of feel-good bilingual bangers. But heavy is the crown.

item.title: James Van Der Beek, star of Dawson's Creek, dies aged 48 after colorectal cancer diagnosis
item.description: The American actor was best known for his starring role as Dawson Leery in Dawson's Creek from 1998 to 2003.

item.title: Heatwave temperatures to peak in south-east Queensland, rain on the way
item.description: A locally intense heatwave will peak across south-east Queensland on Thursday, with incoming rain set to drop temperatures over the weekend.

item.title: Live: Shadow frontbencher quits as Ley backer says Taylor 'ill-prepared'
item.description: Tasmanian Liberal frontbencher Claire Chandler has resigned from the shadow ministry, following Angus Taylor as he prepares to challenge for the party leadership. Follow live.

item.description: A woman's solo hike through regional Victoria took a disturbing turn near Daylesford, raising questions about safety and police responses.

item.title: Live: Australian dollar rises above 71 US cents, ASX to open flat
item.description: Australian stocks are set to open flat after a lacklustre session on Wall Street, with major companies, including Origin Energy, AMP and Temple & Webster, releasing earning results today. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.
